The complex interaction between vegetation activity and ecosystem processes is a crucial area of study. Previous research has established that long-term trends and short-term variability in temperature and precipitation affect vegetation activity. Motivated by the success of Transformer-based Deep Learning models in medium-range weather forecasting, we adapt the publicly available pre-trained FourCastNet model to model vegetation activity while accounting for short-term climate variability. We investigate how the learned global representation of the atmosphere's state can be transferred to model the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI). Our model globally estimates vegetation activity at a resolution of 0.25°, relying only on meteorological data. We demonstrate that leveraging pre-trained weather models improves NDVI estimates compared to learning an NDVI model from scratch. Additionally, we compare our results to other recent data-driven NDVI modeling approaches from machine learning and ecology literature. We also provide experimental evidence on the amount of data and training time required to turn FourCastNet into an effective vegetation model. Code and models are available at https://github.com/LSX-UniWue/Global-Ecosystem-Modeling.

INTRODUCTION

Environmental changes affect the dynamics of terrestrial vegetation, which plays a crucial role in controlling water, energy, and CO2 fluxes, and is essential for providing ecosystem services such as food, fiber, and fuel. A profound understanding of the complex interplay between climate system variables and vegetation changes is necessary for achieving sustainable ecological management. Previous studies have shown that observed changes in vegetation can be attributed to both long-term and short-term changes in temperature and precipitation, i.e., climate change and climate variability.

While the spatial arrangement of vegetation on a large scale is primarily determined by climatic factors, the interplay between climate variability and the short-term dynamics of vegetation introduces a higher level of complexity. Different Machine Learning approaches have been suggested to capture the complex nonlinear dynamics of these short-term dynamics. However, the employed models are either limited to a specific region or use a coarse global resolution with one pixel covering at least 0.5° (approximately 55 km). While there are statistical approaches that globally quantify the effect of climate variability on vegetation change on a finer spatial resolution up to 0.083°, they only consider meteorological data on a coarse time scale, e.g., one data point per month.

The availability of long-term weather reanalysis datasets such as ERA5, which comprises hourly high-resolution measurements of 0.25° (approximately 27 km) per pixel, provides the opportunity to model dependencies of short-term changes in meteorological variables on vegetation activity on a fine spatial and temporal resolution.

Recently, Deep Learning models have demonstrated the capability to efficiently parse and exploit vast amounts of meteorological data in the context of medium-range weather forecasting. Architectural improvements and increased compute availability have led to DL-based weather models that now perform on par with commonly used numerical weather systems. These approaches learn a spatial representation of the atmosphere's state by forecasting future atmospheric states. Previous studies have shown that their trained atmospheric models can be fine-tuned to effectively solve other climate-related tasks such as statistical downscaling and climate projections.

Based on these advances, this work investigates how the pre-trained weather forecasting model FourCastNet (FCN) can be adapted for globally modeling the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), a commonly used index for approximating vegetation activity. We outline an approach building upon a state-of-the-art DL architecture for processing spatio-temporal data, which enables global modeling of the NDVI at a high spatial (0.25°) and temporal (daily) resolution.
